title: Hubert’s Madrean Randonneur: Good Things Are Never Done – Spencer Harding
content:
Today, we have a very special personal randonneur bike from Hubert d’Autremont. With plenty of personal history spanning his framebuilding career, Hubert still says he hates a few lingering unfinished details. Spencer Harding finally got him to take it off the wall and air up the tires for your viewing pleasure. Don’t miss this gallery of rando goodness…

You may know Hubert from his many times up on the site under the banner of Madrean Fabrications. Long before he moved his shop to Tucson, Hubert had been building frames under his full name, Hubert Horacio D’Autremont. What a helluva name.

As with all good bikes, this one starts with a story. In 2015, Hubert and his friend Nick Jet, whom I actually got to meet at an art show recently, planned to tour across the United States, and Hubert planned to build frames for them both. Nick’s frame got built, but Hubert never finished his own frame and never made it out on tour. The frame got tossed under his workbench for years.

Then on New Year’s Day 2020, Hubert was mugged outside his house and he lost his laptop. The next day, his phone died. He was already feeling disconnected from the world when the pandemic hit just a few weeks later. With everything closed down, Hubert turned his attention back toward the touring frame he never finished. Slowly but surely, Hubert finally found the time and focus to finish the frame… almost.

There are a few things that Hubert doesn’t like about the way this bike is built. He’s not satisfied with the decaleur, the light wiring is not routed correctly, and the brake pads are atrocious. Like all great projects, this bike is never done. It remains a labor of love spanning almost a decade. I still felt it was more than worthy to treat your eyes to, despite Hubert’s groaning and deprecation.

The front bag is from a time when Hubert collaborated with friend Matt Renna on a bag and soft goods company called 27th Letter. The name is a reference to the ampersand (&), also known as the 27th letter of the alphabet.

Astute nerds will notice that the Dura Ace downtube shifters are 8-speed, but the XTR derailleur is 9-speed. This era of 8-speed Dura Ace had its own specific cable pull ratio (classic Shimano) and happened to overlap with the pull ratio of later 9-speed XTR. There is a ghost shift at the end of the pull, but it all works perfectly. Hubert had originally planned to do a classic full Campagnolo build, but decided to shirk conventions and do a mix of MUSA and Japanese parts.

Build Spec:

  • Custom frame/fork
  • Shifters: 8-speed Dura Ace downtube
  • Derailleurs: 9-speed XTR
  • Cassette: XTR titanium cassette
  • Pedals: TA Specialties with MKS cages and straps
  • Cranks: TA Specialties (44/34)
  • Brakes: Custom-polished Paul cantilever
  • Brake Lever: Suntour Superbe Pro
  • Headlight: Son Edelux
  • Front Wheel: Son Delux Wide laced to HED Belgium
  • Rear Wheel: Shimano Ultegra laced to HED Belgium
  • Stem: Custom
  • Front Bag: 27th Letter
  • Handlebars: Nitto
  • Seatpost: Shimano Dura Ace
  • Saddle: Brooks Ti rails
  • Headset: Shimano XTR
  • Taillight: Custom

Maybe one day, Hubert will get this bike up to his standard. Maybe it will finally make that journey across the country. Until then, it’s still one helluva randonneur rig!
